text:
Hi! This might seem silly (newb here), but how do you guys run a julia script from the terminal? I understand the precompilation stuff in the REPL and that it is faster when run the next time but say I have a file `demo.jl` and run it from the terminal with `julia demo.jl`, it takes the same amount of time it would take when precompiling. So, in this case, I have to wait for a good amount of time before I see some output. Would be glad if someone could shed some light on this. Thanks.

This is unlike python, where simply running `python demo.py` would render the output regardless of the REPL or terminal environment.
EDIT: Added context through python example.

elements.text: Hi! This might seem silly (newb here), but how do you guys run a julia script from the terminal? I understand the precompilation stuff in the REPL and that it is faster when run the next time but say I have a file
demo.jl
and run it from the terminal with
julia demo.jl

, it takes the same amount of time it would take when precompiling. So, in this case, I have to wait for a good amount of time before I see some output. Would be glad if someone could shed some light on this. Thanks.

This is unlike python, where simply running
python demo.py

would render the output regardless of the REPL or terminal environment.
EDIT: Added context through python example.

text: There are many techniques to reduce the compilation delay. You can use the DaemonMode.jl package, or compile an "app" with PackageCompiler.jl. You can also reduce the compilation levels from command line with e.g. `-O1`

elements.text: There are many techniques to reduce the compilation delay. You can use the DaemonMode.jl package, or compile an "app" with PackageCompiler.jl. You can also reduce the compilation levels from command line with e.g.

text: You can `include("demo.jl")` in a julia REPL and it will simply run everything in the file. That allow you to reuse the REPL and loading/precompilation of packages for example. Other possibilities include running thinks in a IDE (like VScode) that has support for that kind of things, using `Revise.jl` or what Jakob said.

elements.text: You can
include("demo.jl")

in a julia REPL and it will simply run everything in the file. That allow you to reuse the REPL and loading/precompilation of packages for example. Other possibilities include running thinks in a IDE (like VScode) that has support for that kind of things, using
Revise.jl
or what Jakob said.

text:
*Do you mean compiling, or precompiling?* They are different things.
It shouldn’t be *pre*-compiling every time.
If it is something is wrong, probably with how you are using enviroments.
And that needs to totally different solutions to what people are posting here

Once cause could be using Julia older than 1.3 (1.0, 1.1 and 1.2  void the precompilation cache every time you change enviroments).
